bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, December 2, 1941

div1.p: Hench writes that he is sending a copy of Kelly's book on Reed to Wood. He has heard from Mabel Lazear regarding the identification of her husband's handwriting in his notebook.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, December 2, 1941
div1.p:
December 2, 1941 Miss Laura Wood
1338 Nineteenth Street N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Miss Wood:

For four years I have been trying to get two complete sets of
Kelly's book. I never was able to find the third edition. When I visited
Dr. Kelly this Spring I asked him if he knew where I could get one and
the upshot of it was that he insisted on my taking his only copy, which
was his own personal one. I felt rather embarrassed by this generosity
but he insisted that I use it, as a future biographer of Reed. He auto-
graphed it for me and therefore I prize it most highly.

I am sending it to you by separate post and would ask that
you keep it very carefully and return it to me at your convenience. I
did find a couple of copies of the second edition. I had planned to
send one of each edition to be kept at the Washington and Jefferson
College at the Lazear Memorial, but at the present I think you should
have it. Therefore, I am sending it to you to keep, with my best wishes.
Should you be successful in picking up one like it some time (no hurry)
you might trade it for this one, but at any rate I am glad to have you
have it.

I am waiting very impatiently for word from the New York Academy
of Medicine. I wired Malloch today after he did not answer my letter of
last week. But I had a positive print of your photostat made here and airmailed
it to Mrs. Lazear, explaining briefly and hurriedly how it had been discovered.
I have just this minute received an airmail letter with the following: “There
is not the slightest doubt in my mind but that the writing in the photostated
copy you enclose is the handwriting of my husband, Dr. Lazear.....” Thanks
again greatly for your interesting collaboration and help and in return I
am delighted to serve you in any way that I can.

Sincerely,
P. S. Hench, M. D.

1338 19th St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
December 8, 1941 Dear Dr. Hench:

I was so touched and surprised and happy to receive
the Reed book which you so kindly inscribed to me
last Saturday. I shall value it, and all your kind-
nesses, most highly.

I've gone over the two extra chapters in the 3rd
edition and made notes on everything I was inter-
ested in in them, so shall return it immediately
so as to beat the Christmas rush. Surely Kelly is
in error when he says on page 132, in his chapter
on Sternberg, that after becoming Surgeon General
on May 30, 1893, he put Reed at the pathological
laboratory at Hopkins. According to the memoran-
dum the SG's office made for General Kean, Reed
was in Minnesota until the end of August, and then
went straight to Washington. It's a very persis-
tent error. Dr. Flexner also told me when I saw
him in New York that Sternberg had sent Reed to
Hopkins, and so did Dr. William Howard, who wrote
me a long letter about Reed from Hopkins. Another
thing I'm having a hard time checking on is Reed's
first interval at Hopkins when he was stationed at
Ft. McHenry from Feb. 24 to May 2, 1881. Dr. How-
ard said he must have worked with Newell Martin in
the physiological laboratory, but Dr. Wm. H. Howell
who was there at that time as a student says he
doesn't remember him, although he thinks he would
had he been there, and that he isn't listed in the
Johns Hopkins Circular for that year. Do you think
Dr. Kelly is mistaken about it?

I had intended to write and thank you yesterday,
but the commotion was so utter that I couldn't get
my mind back to it. I am, incidentally, especially
pleased with the stamp - I hadn't seen one of them
before - and with your marginal note.. It seems rather trivial to go on working on
a children's book, under the circumstances, but as
a friend of mine, a lawyer, remarked on leaving for
New York on a case last night, “They also serve who
only litigate.” Thank you, again, so much - I am
delighted beyond words to have the book.

Cordially,
Laura Wood
